content: The author, Murasaki Shikibu, was a talented female author born late in the tenth century. From her youth she read romances and waka poetry, and she even learned Chinese writing.
Her father, Fujiwara no Tametoki, was also a splendid man of letters with an outstanding literary pedigree that included famous poets.

The "Kiritsubo" chapter, which begins with the words, "In some royal reign or another, among the many concubines and consorts serving at the court, there was one who, though not of particularly high rank, was more attractive than the rest," contains the story of the love of Hikaru Genji's mother and his father, the emperor, and of Genji, born of their union, until he was the age of twelve.

Murasaki married a man named Fujiwara no Nobutaka at the age of twenty-two or three, but was separated from him by death in less than two years time, and she was left to spend the rest of her life alone.
She apparently even considered becoming a nun at one point, but concerned for her young daughter, she decided to take up service for Shōshi, empress to Emperor Ichijō.

The consort, Kiritsubo, was a woman who was heavily favored by the emperor, but because her social status was low, she bore the brunt of the jealousy of the other ladies at court. Because of this, she eventually became ill and finally died.

Through her hero, Hikaru Genji, Shikibu states, "Romances are filled with fictional events, but in one way of thinking, works like Nihongi contain only a small part of history.  I doubt there is anything that depicts the conditions of society with such skill and detail as the romance."

Focused on Hikaru Genji and his intense, burning love, this long novel (totaling fifty-four chapters) depicts realistically and beautifully the joy, intense pain, happiness and suffering of the many people living in the society of that time.
Born into these circumstances, Hikaru Genji longed for his mother, and he later had complicated relationships with various women serving at court.
The conditions and experiences of life at the imperial court are depicted skillfully in "The Tale of Genji."
It is written that there was not a single woman who, upon seeing         Genji who was so handsome that he shone, was not attracted to him.
The work which depicted the life of this excessively attractive man as clearly as a photograph is "The Tale of Genji."
Genji is, of course, a fictional character created by the talented female author, Murasaki Shikibu (Lady Murasaki).
In that sense, Lady Murasaki was an author of which we can be very proud, not only in Japan, but on a worldwide basis; she is numbered among UNESCO's great people of the world.
I suspect that at this time, very early in the eleventh century, there were very few works anywhere in the world that defined so clearly the position and role of the novel in society.
It seems Don Juan and Casanova are world famous as handsome men, but I doubt they could hold a candle to the beauty and talent of the protagonist of "The Tale of Genji."

V ていく usually describes the process of becoming or growing. It is a process that will continue after a certain time. V ていく can be contrasted with V てくる in that V ていく gives the feeling of process growing away from the speaker, thus becoming more objective or impersonal. On the other hand, V てくる involves the speaker or the process approaching the speaker.

content: With these words as its beginning, "Heike Monogatari" goes on to unfold the history of the defeat and fall of the extremely glorious Taira family, defeated time after time at the hands of the Minamoto forces attacking from the eastern provinces. These opening words set the tone for the whole work, and the sense of the mutability of life held by the people of the day permeates throughout.
The proud are not proud long: they are as a dream of a spring night.
The blossoms of the sal trees reveal the truth that the prosperous must  decline.

The meaning of these words is as follows: Gion Shōja is the name of the Indian temple where the Buddha preached the holy law, and if one listens carefully to the sound of the bell echoing from that temple he/she will come to understand that all things in this world, that is to say, all the works and undertakings of humanity, will quickly disappear and become naught, just as the sound of the bell itself does not last long.

Again, if one observes carefully the blossoms of the sal trees at each corner of his bed when the Buddha died, which blossoms at once turned white and covered him, it is clear at a glance that the glory of those blossoms is short, and they quickly fall.
The sound of the bell of the Gion Shōja echoes the impermanence of all things.
Heike Monogatari, which begins with these famous words, vividly reveals the Japanese sense of the mutability of human life.
The courageous are destroyed in the end: they are as dust before the wind.
In exactly the same manner, power in the world of men is a temporary thing and will quickly decline; the arrogant and boastful who rely on authority to bully and scatter cannot do so forever.
They are exactly like dreams of a spring night, which are no sooner dreamed than they change into another.
They are as dust before the wind. In short, human life is vain.
The powerful and fierce are also destroyed in the end.

なるべく modifies predicates; hence, 〜 is usually an adjective, an adverb, or a verb.  It often goes with an expression of volition, request, command, or suggestion.

This の is sometimes called “extended predicate” and usually refers to the reason or explanation.

This structure comes from a more common structure 〜ても, even if.  Often, 〜 is a general statement.

content: X とする: It is supposed that 〜

lesson: This form indicates supposition on the part of the speaker.
例. x + 2 をAとすると、3 (x + 2) は3Aになる。

This phrase is often used to avoid the strong assertion of the speaker by transferring to the person who made the statement. Hence, here the statement "We have entered the global civilization" is the professor's assertion and not the author's.

すら is used to express the feeling of something that you would expect from N at least, but even N not coming through as you expected. This construction comes from a more general structure N (particle) + すら: When the N (noun) is the subject or the direct object of the sentence, then the particles are deleted.
例1. 日本人すら来なかった。

In sentence 1, you would expect the Japanese to come for sure (at least Japanese would come.), but even they didn’t show up. However, if there are some particles in a sentence before adding すら, they are maintained as in sentences 2.
例2. 隣の町にすら行けなかった。
He could not even go to the next town.

In 2, you would expect for him to at least go to the next town but he was not even able to go. Although this structure is often used with negative sentences, they do not have to be negative as in the following example.
例3. あの人は夏ですらセーターを着ている。
He wears sweaters even in the summer.
This structure is formal and used more in writing. ごとく acts as a pseudonoun.
例1. ユーフォーが光のごとく飛び去った。
The UFO flew away in a flash.
例2. ただ春の夜の夢のごとし。
They are as a dream of a spring night.

content: While the extent and scope may be different due to human knowledge and accompanying technology, using the "outside" as a basis for creating the "inside" of a country is a universal human characteristic, and at the very least it is a habit of the Japanese.
However, with the world shrinking this small because of technology, it is hard to decide who or what is "outside" and who or what is "inside."
In the now-departed 20th century, because of these borders, these man-made lines, many people lost their lives.

As a teaching says in the Analects of Confucius, "look to the past         for the future," we must learn from history to know what endeavors we         humans should undertake in the future in this increasingly smaller world.
I look forward to the future to see what sort of world and history the people who live in this time will create.
We are even starting to see people who have concerns with the very concepts of countries and borders in the first place.
However, there is probably nothing that has changed Japan as much as the post-war influence of America.
Japan has looked abroad since the time when it started to be unified.
This influence is so powerful that, without words imported from America, one cannot speak Japanese anymore.
After the Meiji Restoration, European concepts and technology changed the entire country of Japan in the movement towards civilized enlightenment.

Even in the isolation period, when association with foreign countries was prohibited, the "Dutch Studies" that entered Japan through Dejima became the foundation of the train of thought of the people who changed Japan at the end of the Shogunate era.

It would not be an exaggeration to say that Japanese history was greatly changed by the Christian missionaries and barbarian merchants who brought new millitary tactics and religion from Europe (especially of Spain and Portugal).
The new millennium has started, and it is said to be a period of change not only for the Japanese but all people.

As in the sixteenth century, when Copernicus corrected the theory that the sun revolved around the earth with his theory that the earth revolves around the sun, we must change from a country-centered view of the world to a world-centered view of the world.

The influence of China at the time of the delegations from Japan to the Sui and Tang dynasties extended not just to the cities of Nara and Kyōto, but to the normal lifestyle of the Japanese as well, as can be seen in the language and literature of the time.
Just as Kamo no Chōmei wrote, "the bubbles in quiet pools disappear and form," even though the time, place, and scale may be different.
It seems that we will not be able to eliminate conflicts, civil disturbances, and war in the near future.
In other words, we must focus on the "outside" and realize that the "inside" is but one of it's parts.
A famous British historian, Professor Baraclaugh,         said that now is a period of "global civilization (world-wide global civilization)."

World War I and World War II:  the great wars that enveloped the entire world, the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the Gulf War - this has been a hundred-year period that would well be named the world's period of warring states.
Just like the town of our birth and its traditions cannot be forgotten easily in life, we cannot simply ignore our home country, rather, quite to the contrary, we must learn from it.
But, no matter how global this world becomes, people cannot just be told to abandon a healthy nationalism and patriotism.
And in the 21st century, just as we thought we had overcome Y2K, an unheard of outbreak of terrorism hit America and started the Afghanistan War.

content: The Shogunate, no longer able by any means to continue the national isolation policy, at last decided to enter into the Japan-U.S. Friendship Treaty and end the isolation policy.

In 1860, however, on his way through the snow to the Edo Castle to attend the peach festival, Ii Naosuke, the Shogunate's elder statesman (equivalent to the current Prime Minister) was stabbed to death outside the castle's Sakuradamon Gate.
To arrest these loyalists, the Shogunate clamped down severely by selecting elite warriors to form a group known as Shinsengumi (secret police).

Having lost its elder statesman, Ii, the Shogunate quickly declined in power and, no longer able to suppress the "revere the emperor and expel the barbarians" movement which had changed their slogan to "revere the emperor and overthrow the Shogunate," finally returned political power to the emperor.

Thus, with the attainment of the throne by the Emperor (Meiji), the shift of the capital from Kyōto to Edo, and the change of the name of Edo to Tōkyō (Eastern Capital) in 1868, Japan set out to establish a modern nation state.
Members of the "revere the emperor and expel the barbarians" movement were known as imperial loyalists; their power base grew around the imperial court in Kyōto.

The people at the center of the movement to "revere the emperor and expel the barbarians" were Saigō Takamori of the Satsuma fief (currently Kagoshima Prefecture) and Katsura Kogorō of the Chōshū fief (modern Yamaguchi Prefecture).
The Japanese, who had had no relations with foreigners for a long time, were greatly disturbed by the opening of their country.

Those who advocated the policy to keep out foreigners (known as jōironsha), feeling that beginning foreign trade would throw Japanese society into disarray, joined with those advocating reverence to the emperor (sonnōronsha) and fought fiercely against those who tried diligently to sustain the Shogunate.
The Japanese, who until that point had no relations with foreigners outside Dejima in Nagasaki and who had never heard of the West's modern development and discoveries, were very surprised.

The U.S. commander, Admiral Perry, left Japan temporarily after         handing the Shogunate the official request from the U.S. president to         open up the nation, but returned the following year to the Edo Bay with         seven warships to request opening the relationships.
Four large ships the likes of which no Japanese had ever seen sailed into the Uraga Harbor billowing smoke from their smokestacks.

content: The warriors throughout the country divided into two camps. One camp allied with the Genji, the other allied with the Heike, and they fought one another.

Though Taira no Kiyomori had been a warrior as well, after defeating         the Genji and beginning to govern, he pretended to be of the nobility         and conducted his government and lifestyle exactly as had the nobility.
On the other hand, Yoritomo, not imitating the politics and lifestyle of the nobles, created a government of the military.
Initially, Taira no Kiyomori, the commander of the Heike, defeated Minamoto no Yoshitomo, commanding general of the Genji, and began ruling the country.
The battles between the Genji and the Heike are filled with many very interesting episodes, and many stories were written treating them.
Kiyomori must have thought that if they studied Buddhist teachings at a temple, and perhaps even became priests, they would not think to try to avenge their father's death.
However, one of Yoshitomo's sons, Yoritomo, was exiled to Izu island while the other son, infant Yoshitsune, was spared by Kiyomori and entrusted to a temple.
In this respect, the Kamakura period is very significant in Japanese history.
Though a military chronicle, it is a skillful work that brings neither the bloodiness nor the sense of victory and defeat of war.
At first, warriors were utilized to fight in succession disputes between emperors and nobility, but gradually, as their power increased, they began to fight for power among themselves.
The most powerful of the warrior [families] were the Genji and the Heike.
Heike Monogatari was not merely read as a book, but was also chanted to the people by biwa hōshi (lute priests) who traveled the whole of Japan.
Those whose power grew in place of the nobility were the military.

Against the backdrop of the Seto Inland Sea, it depicts with indescribable beauty the powerful figure of the Genji warriors lead by Yoshitsune and the pitiful end of the Heike as they fled ever westward from Kyōto.
I feel the most representative of these is "Heike Monogatari."

Just as the most beautiful blossom will eventually wither and fall,         the nobility who had enjoyed a luxurious and beautiful lifestyle gradually         lost power with each passing day as the end of the Heian period approached.
No doubt people of old listened keenly to the lonely chanting of "Heike Monogatari" by the wandering biwa hoshi just as we today enjoy music and drama on T.V. and radio.
Biwa hōshi were usually blind, and chanted their tales to the accompaniment of lutes - musical instruments resembling the guitar.
Encouraged and aided by warriors who harbored dissatisfaction with the Heike, the brothers Yoritomo and Yoritsune at length completely destroyed the Heike.
Yoritomo established a Bakufu (military government) in Kamakura in 1192 and carried out Japan's first military government.

content: He lost his father and older brother at an early age and thought he would succeed his father as a Shintō priest, but the position was usurped from him by a relative, and he was unable to advance in the world.
Utilizing a parallel sentence structure, he skillfully depicts the vanity of city life of the time, and the Buddhist sense of mutability.
It also depicts the foolishness of humanity pouring wasted money         and energy into worldly things that, with the passage of time, are destroyed         in that way.
Chōmei (his name may also be read Nagaakira) was the second         son born to the Chief Priest of the Shimogamo Shrine, a shrine near Kyōto.
There Chōmei reflected back on his life, and began writing his "Hōjōki," which includes the words, "I realized of myself the brevity of my fate."

These beginning words are well-known enough that all Japanese are familiar with them.  Changed to modern Japanese the passage reads, "The water that streams in a flowing river never comes to a stop, but the water that flows there now is not the same as the original water. Of the bubbles floating on the stagnant pools, which seem to disappear at one moment and appear in another, there are none that last very long. The people living in this world and their houses are like that too."
I feel these are words that express very well the sense of evanescence of the Japanese of the time regarding human life.
Hōjōki writes about various worldly disturbances and disasters that occurred at the time.
The current of a flowing river never ceases, yet its water is never the same.

It is said that Chōmei, who shut himself up in a mountain to escape the emptiness of the world, placed on one side of his hut his beloved koto and biwa, besides which he provided for himself nothing else but Buddhist worship objects, including the Lotus Sutra and a portrait of Amida.
People in this world and their houses are the same.
In the last half of his essay, he depicts his life after becoming a priest, and explains how tasteful and relaxed a quiet lifestyle, not posing difficulty to others, is.
The bubbles that float on the stagnant pools, at one moment disappearing, in the next forming, never last long

Nevertheless, he ends the last part of his essay with the following soliloquy: "Although I have confined myself in the forest in order to discipline my heart and avoid worldly pollutions, my heart, after all, is still defiled, and I have been unable to become a saint. I don't understand whether I suffer as a just retribution from a former existence, or just because of my confused heart.  All that is left is to quietly recite the nembutsu, 'Namu Amida Butsu,' from however defiled a heart."

Hōjōki is highly appraised today as a work which skillfully depicts the emotions of people of the medieval age, but Chōmei, who spent a lonely life alone in the midst of the mountains, surely never expected the essay he left behind to be read by so many people.
Hōjōki (An Account of My Hut), which begins with the above words, is an essay written in the 13th Century by Kamo no Chōmei.
Furthermore, I am certain he never even dreamed it would be translated even into English and read by foreigners.
Resentful of this untrustworthy world, Chōmei, now more than 40 years old, took Buddhist vows, hid himself in a place called Ōhara, and led a quiet life of seclusion.
Later he moved to a mountain called Hino Toyama, where he built a small (about 10 feet square) hermitage, and spent the rest of his short life.

〜こと makes the sentence more abstract.         In other words, the speaker makes the statement more detached from him         or her. Oftentimes it is used in narration. With でしょう the speakers conjecture         added, it is a very detached, sometimes polite conjecture of the speaker.

This structure is used to indicate the speaker's denial of X, which might be inferred and expected from the context.  Translated, it means, "You might expect X; far from being X, it is Y."
例1. うれしいどころか、悲しくてどうしていいのかわかりません。

content: The answer Nichiren received was that the various sects people believed at the time, including Jōdo and Zen, were all mistaken; that the true teachings of Buddhism lie in the Lotus Sutra; and that the reason the country of Japan was meeting with various disasters was that the people believed in mistaken sects.
Nichiren, who began teaching such notions, received tremendous persecution from believers of other sects.

However, not only was the country not peaceful, but the emperor, who was thought of as representing the people, had drowned himself in the sea, and members of the imperial family had become engulfed in political battles between warriors and had died tragic deaths.
The country of Japan at that time also accepted that notion, and         most people believed in Buddhism.
Thus it was that the Nichiren Sect came to put down deep roots throughout Japan.
After the prophecies were fulfilled, people and government officials         who had opposed him to that point began to believe and respect him.
This prophecy was fulfilled by the first foreign invasion in Japanese history, known as Genkō (the Mongol Invasions).
Nichiren was particularly despised by many people because he adopted a proselyting method called shakubuku by which he confronted directly and argued face-on with people who opposed him.
He also had many near death experiences, including confinement in caves, being nearly forced to drink poison, and exile to Izu and Sado Islands.
And he began to prophesy that if Japan did not abandon mistaken sects and follow the Lotus Sutra, it would surely be invaded by foreign countries.
He was, however, conscious from the beginning that in order to teach right teachings and become a saint he would be required to undergo such suffering.
At the age of twelve, he was beset by two questions to which he         simply could not find satisfactory answer.
The other question was how there could be so many different sects in Buddhism, purportedly the true religion.
One of his doubts was just how such a thing was possible.
Thus, surely he was very familiar with the sacred chant "Namu Amida Butsu" (hail to Amida Buddha) from his young childhood.
In order to resolve his two doubts, the young man resolved firmly to investigate everything in Japan, becoming the most knowledgeable, and discover which sect of Buddhism was most nearly correct.
Both questions related to religion, but one had to do with history and politics.
That is to say, in Buddhism it was believed that if a country was governed on the basis of Buddhist law, the country would be quiet and peaceful.
So he entered the priesthood at the age of sixteen and began his         study of Buddhist scripture.
That was when Nichiren was thirty-two.
His was a poor fishing household, and his mother and father were diligent members of the Jōdo Sect of Buddhism which prospered in the world in general at the time.
Thirty years after that a boy was born in a small fishing village in Awa Province (currently Awa District, Chiba Prefecture).
Then, after discovering a basic resolution to his two questions         in the scriptures, he descended Mt. Hiei and began explaining his own         beliefs.
In 1185, the child emperor Antoku, chased into a corner by the Genji who were led by Minamoto no Yoshitsune, threw himself into the waters of the Seto Inland Sea and died with the Heike.
It was this young man who was [to become] Nichiren, a man who influenced  Japanese religion for a long time to come.
In order to resolve his two questions, Nichiren studied at various temples, including some in Kamakura, and eventually climbed Mt. Hiei, the center of Buddhism at the time, to practice austerities.
In 1192 Minamoto no Yoritomo established the bakufu in Kamakura.

content: There was very little knowledge and information about Japan overseas.
And within Japan itself outstanding physicians and scholars came to Nagasaki and studied Dutch learning.
At that time the Dutch at Dejima journeyed to Edo once a year to take gifts to the Shōgun as an expression of gratitude. Siebold joined the entourage and went to Edo as well.

Siebold had a daughter by a Japanese woman, and he no doubt left Nagasaki feeling his heart would break, leaving his child and her mother behind, never to return to his beloved Japan again.
On account of that, over the next nearly 250 years, Japan developed a civilization and culture uniquely Japanese with very little influence from foreign countries.

The term "cultural enlightenment" refers to the rapid adoption of a new civilization in place of the old in the Meiji era.

Further, until that time warriors fashioned their hair into topknots, and were distinct from the farmers and townsmen, but with the beginning of Meiji they were required to cut off their topknots and become entirely equal with other classes.
